questions.text: A study followed individuals from childhood to adulthood and found that those with lower blood pressure as children continued to have lower blood pressure as adults, while those with higher childhood blood pressure maintained higher levels into adulthood. Which concept best explains this observation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The blood pressure of an individual is tracked from childhood to adulthood in the tracking phenomenon of blood pressure.

  • This is a very useful tool in the early diagnosis of hypertension, even among adolescents/ young adults.
  • If a person is hypotensive in childhood, they remain hypotensive in adulthood.
  • If a person is hypertensive in childhood, they remain hypertensive in adulthood.
  • This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure has been described as tracking.

Tracking of blood pressure

Explanation for other options:

Rules of Halves (Option A):

The concept of the "Rule of Halves" in hypertension management illustrates that:

  • Approximately 50% of individuals with hypertension are aware of their condition.
  • Among those aware, only about 50% receive treatment.
  • Out of those receiving treatment, approximately 50% have their blood pressure adequately controlled.

Stepwise approach (Option C): is a systematic, multi-step method designed to collect noncommunicable disease risk factor data at the population level using a questionnaire, physical assessments, and biochemical tests.

Primordial approach (Option D):

  • Focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in the first place.
  • Targets social, economic, and environmental conditions that contribute to disease.
  • Focuses on preventing risk factors before they develop (e.g., lifestyle interventions in childhood to prevent hypertension in adulthood).
  • This does not describe the observation in the question.

questions.text: What does the metric "years of potential life lost" primarily measure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Years of potential life lost due to premature death.

  • Example: If a 30-year-old dies, they potentially lose 45 years of life (assuming a life expectancy of 75).
  • YPLL is a mortality indicator, less sensitive in developed nations with better disease control.

Years lost to morbidity (Option A): YPLL refers to premature death, not morbidity.

questions.text: A study is being conducted to evaluate the link between aniline dye exposure and the development of bladder cancer in industrial workers with more than 20 years of employment. One group includes workers directly handling the dye, while the other consists of office staff with no direct exposure. Employment duration is obtained from existing records. What type of study design does this represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A retrospective cohort study is a combination of a prospective cohort study and a case-control study.

  • The researcher goes back in time and selects study groups from existing past medical records and traces them forward.
  • In this case, records of the aniline dye handlers were noted to study the close association with bladder cancer.

Retrospective Cohort Study

  • Start studying at present
  • Move backwards (retrospectively) and use historical data
  • Based on historical data, divide study participants into exposed and non-exposed groups.
  • Ex: Based on the Medical College Register of 2010, divide students into exposed and non-exposed groups
  • Determine outcomes (diseased and non-diseased rates) at the time the study begins.
  • They produce faster results than prospective cohort studies.
  • It has been used for the study of lung carcinoma in uranium miners, arsenic in carcinogenesis, angiosarcoma of the liver, and radiation exposure in physicians.

Explanation for other options:

Prospective cohort study (Option B):

  • In this study, the disease had not yet occurred when the investigation started.
  • The investigation starts from the present and proceeds to the future.
  • A few examples are studies on smoking and lung cancer, studies of oral contraceptives and health.

Case-control study (Option C):

  • It starts with the disease and, hence, it proceeds from effect to cause.
  • Quicker results are noticed.
  • It is suitable for the study of rare diseases and is relatively cheap.

Intervention and response (Option D):

  • It is also called an experimental study.
  • Intervention and response involve direct control over the study, unlike observational cohort studies.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida presents with complaints of night blindness and reports avoiding specific fruits during pregnancy out of fear they might cause miscarriage. Who is primarily responsible for providing her with appropriate counselling and information in this situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Although all of the above can do this job, the single best answer is ASHA Worker.

  • The pregnant woman is likely to be suffering from Vitamin A deficiency due to poor intake of foods rich in vitamin A.
  • The primary duty of the ASHA worker is to go for home visits and to counsel regarding sanitation, nutrition, living conditions, and family welfare services.
  • She helps in mobilising the community to access health care facilities available at the PHC/Anganwadi/sub-centre.

Explanation for other options:

ANM (Option A): ANM ensures thorough training of the ASHA worker.

AWW (Option B): They are part-time workers. She undergoes training for 4 months in various sectors like health, nutrition, and child development.

Trained birth attendant (Option D): They ensure safe delivery, monitor maternal and fetal well-being, promote a positive birthing experience by reducing stress and anxiety during labour, promote exclusive breastfeeding, and are trained to identify and rectify any labour complications.

questions.text: During a disease outbreak, what is the correct method for collecting a water sample for bacteriological analysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct method involves collecting from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing.

  • Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, let the water flow for at least 2 minutes.
  • Hold the bottle at the base with one hand.
  • Water from leaky taps is avoided.
  • Before collecting samples for taps that are not regularly used, the taps are sterilised by heating either with a blow lamp or a piece of cotton that is soaked in methylated spirit.

Sample for physical and chemical examination:

  • Collection glass: Winchester Quart bottles
  • Capacity: > 2L
  • Pre-collection: Rinse well thrice with water
  • Collection
    • Fill with water
    • Tight placement of the stopper with a piece of cloth
    • Seal the string

Sample for bacteriological examination:

  • Collection glass: Clean bottle made of neutral glass
  • Capacity: 200-250 ml
  • If the sample is likely to have chlorine, 0.1 ml of sodium thiosulfate is added before cleaning.

Transport and storage of the sample:

  • Precaution: Keep the sample on ice till it's taken for analysis.
  • Analysis: Should be done within 48 hours of collection
  • Details
    • Date and time of collection
    • Source
    • Survey findings

Explanation for other options:

Collecting water from already leaking taps (Option A) is avoided as it can contaminate the sample if the water runs outside the tap and enters the bottle.

Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute (Option B): Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, the water flow is allowed for at least 2 minutes and not for 1 minute.

Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage (Option C): Keeping the water sample container close to the tap can cause the contaminants from the tap to pass into the water container.

questions.text: An outbreak of fever accompanied by headache has occurred in a boys' hostel, with affected individuals later developing pleomorphic rashes that spare the palms and soles. What should be the next best step in managing the suspected cases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The probable diagnosis, in this case, is chicken pox, also called varicella, which is caused by the Varicella zoster virus. So, control measures include isolation of the child for 6 days after the onset of rashes, and disinfecting all materials that are contaminated by nasal or throat secretions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presents with a one-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Although both sputum smear tests are negative, the chest X-ray findings are suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the latest NTEP guidelines, what should be the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the NTEP guidelines, a negative smear with positive chest X-ray findings would require a CBNAAT.

  • It is the current gold standard for the diagnosis of tuberculosis within 90 minutes.

Explanation for other options:

Repeat sputum smears (Option A): Previously, it was done, but not done after 2016. Repeat sputum smears are taken to monitor the treatment response.

Ask for line probe assay (Option C): Line probe assay is usually used for the diagnosis of the first-line antitubercular drug resistance tuberculosis, and is not indicated in this case scenario.

Wait until TB culture results to start ATT (Option D): Since it is slow-growing, it takes around 4 weeks to get the sputum culture reports. Hence, it is not ideal to depend on culture reports to start ATT.

questions.text: What term describes the average daily intake level of a nutrient that is adequate to meet the needs of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals within a specific age and gender group?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) is the average dietary nutrient intake sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

  • It is derived from the individual variability and bioavailability of the nutrients from the diet.
  • It is the level of nutrient intake that is essential to meet all dietary requirements.

Explanation for other options:

Adequate intake (Option A): It is the recommended average daily intake level based on observed or experimentally determined estimations of nutrient intake by a group of apparently healthy people, which are assumed to be adequate.

Dietary goal (Option B): 15-30 % of total daily intake should consist of fats, 10 % should be contributed by saturated fats, and 10-15% should be contributed by proteins. Salt intake should be less than 5 g/day, refined carbohydrates should be limited, and alcohol consumption should be restricted. Junk food consumption should also be restricted.

Estimated average requirement (Option C): It is the average daily nutrient intake level estimated to meet the requirements of half of the healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.
